title: Do Authors make money for library books? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, Libraries buy the books the loan just like individuals…then they lend them out at no cost to members of the community. Ben Franklin and fellow members of the Junto Club created one of the first lending libraries in the Colonies (the American Revolution hadn’t happened yet) on July 1st, 1731. Here is a short history Lending Library - Benjamin Franklin Historical Society Public Libraries have since been called “the People’s University”. The American Library Association champions open and equal access Access to Library Resources and Services “Equity extends beyond equality—fairness and universal access—to deliberate and intentional efforts to create service delivery models that will make sure that community members have the resources they need. Often these needs are different not only as the result of race and ethnicity but also owing to religious beliefs, sexual orientation, gender identification, socioeconomic status, or physical ability. Libraries are major sources of information for society and they serve as guardians of the public’s access to information. The advent of the digital world has revolutionized how the public obtains its information and how libraries provide it. As the digital world continues to evolve, libraries help ensure that people can access the information they need – regardless of age, education, ethnicity, language, income, physical limitations or geographic barriers. Core values of the library community such as equal access to information, intellectual freedom, and the objective stewardship and provision of information must be preserved and strengthened, now more than ever. For intellectual freedom to flourish, opposition to censorship of materials is not enough. Access to materials, without prejudice, to every member of the community must also be assured. As one of the core values of librarianship, ‘Equality of access to recorded knowledge and information’ which involves ‘insuring that all library resources are accessible to all overcoming technological and monetary barriers to access’ goes hand in hand with democracy and freedom.” Bonus: Here are 9 Unexpected Benefits That Come with Having a Library Card. A library near me loans seeds to gardeners (they bring seeds from what they grow back at the end of the season) Bainbridge seed library cultivates community. The New York Public Library loans handbags and ties to people dressing for interviews This library loans out ties and handbags so those with limited resources can go to job interviews . Here are 18 Weird Things You Can Borrow From Your Local Library. Check out YOUR local library and see what they offer beyond books.

I can only answer for the United States. For print books, authors make their money from the sale of the book(s) to the library. That’s it. It’s a one-time payment. Granted, that book will get worn and need replacing, so long as it’s even somewhat popular. And libraries who buy one book by an author are likely to buy more—again, provided it’s even a little popular. Authors also generally embrace libraries carrying copies of their work. (As you can see in Lawrence Watt-Evans’s answer.) Circulating copies of library books draw in more readers, and if they like the book, they’re likely to talk about it to friends and family, pulling in more interest. If they really like it, they might buy their own copy. That’s happened to me several times now. And here I thought that if I worked at a library, I would spend less money on books… Anyway, that’s just for print. Ebooks are a different matter altogether. When a library carries an ebook (or e-audiobook) they’re only licensing it from the publisher. That license is only valid for a certain number of circulations. Once that number is reached, the library has to pay to license the book again. My understanding—and I welcome correction if this is wrong—is that the author receives royalties for every such license, provided they’ve earned out their advance.

It partly depends what country you’re in. Several countries have what they call “Public Lending Rights,” where authors living in that country do get a small royalty for each time a library loans out one of their books. The UK does this, and I’m pretty sure some of the Scandinavian countries; not sure where else. (I believe Canada has considered it, but I don’t know if it ever went into effect.) It’s paid for out of general taxes, library patrons don’t pay any fees or anything. The U.S. does not have public lending rights payments. Of course, every copy of a book that a library buys pays the regular royalty rate. You might think writers would resent all those people reading their books for free, but most of us were readers first, and love libraries. We consider it part of recruiting more readers.

Yes, but not directly. Authors are paid by their publisher for every copy of their book sold. It makes no difference if the sale is made to an individual over the counter in a book store, ordered and delivered by mail, or bought by an institution, for example a hospital, nursing home, prison, school, or library. All of these sales result in a payment to the author, but none of these buyers send a payment to the author. The author's cut is contained in the book's price. Libraries do not receive their books free; we pay for each book we accession. (It is true that we sometimes receive donations, but those books have been bought by someone, and the author got his cut. The standard word for the author's cut is "royalty.")

When they purchase the book hopefully the author is getting paid for that purchase so in that sense, yes. But the author is not paid per use, no. While I’m not sure on the particulars it’s possible authors end up with more royalties when libraries purchase digital collections that include their book. Depending on the licensing agreements a book may be able to be borrowed by multiple people at the same time, this is essentially like purchasing two copies of a book. The cost for the digital library may be cheaper per book for the subscription period but subscriptions have to be renewed so the library will be paying again eventually. Not sure how the numbers work out for sure though.

Libraries buy the book like anyone else, usually through a reseller and the author gets some of that via their publisher. In New Zealand Libraries’ right to purchase and lend material is legislated and this allows them to do a couple of things that might otherwise be thought to contradict copyright. However, one year when I was studying to be a librarian I had a couple of weeks work making a list of all the books held by New Zealand authors in the Teachers College library I was working in. This list was used by the New Zealand Book Council, I believe, to offer NZ authors compensation for presumed list earnings. It’s also worth noting that numerous studies have shown that areas with healthy public library systems pend more on books than areas without, as libraries create and develop readers at all ages.

The library buys the books from the publisher and the author gets those royalties. That's basically it. There is potentially a discount that publishers might offer libraries but I don't think that cuts into author profits. There is also the addition of new readers. If they get the first free from a library, they might seek out the rest of a series in book shops if they enjoyed it. This is especially the case where libraries only stock one book in a trilogy (usually book 2 😉).

Libraries in the United States buy their copies (usually from wholesalers who sell to libraries and provide some additional services like cataloging records, shelving labels, etc.) and the authors are paid for those sales in agreement with whatever the contractual agreements say. There’s no additional payment to authors beyond the sale. However, some countries and locations do have an additional payment to authors based on loans. (The United Kingdom does this, but I am not familiar with all the details, just that it’s up to a certain amount per year per author. That’s through the Public Lending Rights scheme.) However, those payments are made by the library, and are based on the number of loans, so if a book doesn’t circulate, there isn’t an additional cost.

No, not directly anyway. Libraries purchase books from publishers, often through an intermediary source that buys large quantities of books from many publishers at a bulk discount then sells them to libraries. And of course the publishers pay the authors. Occasionally a library may buy a book directly from the author; for example, if a local author has written a self-published book about events in the town or community where the library is located.

Yes. Libraries in the US are very good for authors! Libraries buy books at wholesale, so the author still gets their full royalty share. A library can lend a copy of a book X-number of times before they have to rebuy that book. Often, this number is up in the high 20s. If a library lends out the book 27 times, they have to buy another copy. A popular book may get repurchased many times by libraries—sometimes they buy multiple copies at the same time! For each copy, the author gets their royalty.

In the US, only on royalties paid when the library buys the book. There are no royalties paid if a book is borrowed. In the UK and certain other countries, authors do get paid a small fee each time a book is checked out. (“Public Lending Right”) https://www.bl.uk/plr PLR International
Libraries must buy the books that they make available to the public, so you could say that they pay the author. Books are normally purchased through a publishing house.
No. Libraries do not pay authors. Libraries are funded by government and contributions to purchase materials and keep thier doors open. They are not a money making institution
Libraries buy their books like anyone else. The author gets a royalty from the sale just as they do when you buy it. That’s all.
Libraries buy their books from publishers and booksellers. They don’t buy directly from an author.
No the libraries purchase the book authors do not charge additional fees.
